uksc-2015-0177: The case involves Littlewoods Ltd and HM Revenue & Customs (HMRC) regarding the recovery of overpaid VAT.
Littlewoods argued it was entitled to interest on the overpaid VAT.
The court considered the principles of effectiveness and equivalence under EU law.
The principle of effectiveness requires national rules on interest to provide adequate indemnity for undue tax payments.
The principle of equivalence requires national interest rules to be equivalent to those under the VAT Act 1994.
The court concluded that the VAT Act 1994, as amended, did not allow for the recovery of interest on overpaid VAT.
The court found the national interest rules were not equivalent to those under the VAT Act 1994.
The decision may impact taxpayers who have overpaid VAT by limiting their ability to recover through interest.
The case has implications for the calculation of interest in VAT recovery cases.
The judgment is significant for legal journalists reporting on EU law and tax recovery.
uksc-2009-0105: The case involved a Jewish man, M, who was not recognized as Jewish by the Orthodox Chief Rabbinate of the United Kingdom.
M's mother converted to Judaism through a Reform rabbi, which led to his lack of recognition by the Orthodox community.
M argued that the school's admissions policy indirectly discriminated against him based on ethnicity.
The school's policy prioritized Jewish applicants for admissions.
The case was brought before the UK Supreme Court under the Equality Act 2010.
The Supreme Court held that the school's policy was based on religious grounds, not racial ones.
The court found that the policy did not have a disproportionate impact on a particular racial group.
The Supreme Court ruled that the admissions policy amounted to indirect discrimination.
The court determined that the policy was not justified by a legitimate aim.
The court emphasized that the school's aim was to educate children recognized as Jewish by the Orthodox community.
uksc-2017-0040: Mr. Mills and Mrs. Mills were involved in a divorce settlement in 2002.
Mrs. Mills received a large capital sum as part of the divorce settlement.
Mrs. Mills used the capital sum to purchase a house.
Mrs. Mills made poor financial decisions that led to a financial shortfall.
Mr. Mills argued that he should not continue making periodical payments to Mrs. Mills.
The lower court ruled that Mr. Mills should pay 60% of the rent.
The lower court found that Mr. Mills could afford to continue making the periodical payments.
Mrs. Mills appealed, requesting higher payments and a fixed payment period.
Mr. Mills also appealed, arguing he could not afford the payments.
The Court of Appeal dismissed both appeals and upheld the lower court's decision.
uksc-2011-0046: The Equality Act 2010, section 1(6), prevents employers from being used as a proxy for comparing employment terms between men and women.
The purpose of section 1(6) is to ensure women are not disadvantaged in pay and employment conditions due to employer actions.
Claimants were women employed by a local authority seeking to compare their conditions with manual workers under a different collective agreement.
The employment tribunal initially ruled in favor of the claimants, finding their work was of equal value to manual workers.
The local authority appealed, arguing the tribunal misapplied the legal test for equal value jobs.
The Court of Session agreed with the local authority, stating the tribunal did not consider the "real possibility" test.
The court introduced the "real possibility" test, requiring comparators to be hypothetically transferable to the same establishment.
The court emphasized that the same employer test should not be used to avoid complex equal value or equivalent job tests.
The court noted that section 1(6) aims to eliminate geography-based disparities in employment terms.
The decision highlights the need for employers to ensure fair pay and conditions for all employees.
uksc-2011-0115: The DPP has the power to take over a private prosecution under section 6(1) of the 1985 Criminal Justice Act.
The DPP can also discontinue a private prosecution under the same section.
The Supreme Court examined the DPP's powers and responsibilities under the 1985 Criminal Justice Act.
The Full Code Test is a two-stage process used to determine whether to prosecute.
The Supreme Court held that the DPP's policy sets a higher evidential threshold than the Full Code Test.
The DPP's policy requires a case to be clearly unfounded before it can be discontinued.
The Court found the DPP's policy inconsistent with the Full Code Test.
The Full Code Test requires a realistic prospect of conviction and a public interest in prosecution.
The DPP's policy was found to undermine the fundamental right to private prosecution.
The Supreme Court concluded that the DPP's policy was unlawful and should be struck down.
uksc-2010-0127: The case involves a dispute over the interpretation of a subclause in a bond agreement.
The appellants argue for a construction that aligns with business common sense.
The respondents advocate for a literal interpretation of the contract language.
The legal principles emphasize balancing literal meaning with the commercial purpose of the contract.
Judicial decisions from the House of Lords and the Court of Appeal support the use of commercial sense in contract interpretation.
The judge suggested that ambiguous contract language should be construed in a way that aligns with business common sense.
The appellants contended that the judge's approach was overly broad.
The Court of Appeal concluded that the contract's language could be interpreted in two ways.
Both interpretations could potentially achieve the landlords' desired outcome.
The case highlights the importance of considering the context and reasonable expectations of the parties in contract construction.
uksc-2010-0039: The "without prejudice" rule in English law allows parties to negotiate settlements without fear of communications being used as evidence.
The "without prejudice" rule is not absolute and has established exceptions.
The case of Cutts v United Kingdom [1977] 1 WLR 1174 clarified the scope of the "without prejudice" rule.
The House of Lords in Cutts v United Kingdom held that evidence of negotiations may be admitted if negotiations are not in good faith.
The House of Lords in Cutts v United Kingdom allowed the admission of evidence if communications were made with the intention of misleading the court.
The case of Unilever plc v Miles Far East Corporation [1997] 1 Lloyd's Rep 591 distinguished between the "without prejudice" rule and contract interpretation.
The House of Lords in Unilever plc v Miles Far East Corporation clarified that the "without prejudice" rule does not prevent the use of negotiations to interpret contractual terms.
The case of Chartbrook Ltd v Persimmon Homes Ltd [2009] UKHL 38 is relevant to the issue of admissibility of negotiation evidence.
The House of Lords in Chartbrook Ltd v Persimmon Homes Ltd held that evidence of the factual matrix is admissible to interpret a contract.
The "without prejudice" rule is designed to promote candid negotiations between parties to a dispute.
uksc-2010-0231: The appellants are offshore workers seeking to take annual leave during onshore field break periods.
The employers require appellants to take annual leave during offshore periods.
The Court of Appeal ruled that appellants are entitled to take annual leave during onshore field break periods.
The Working Time Directive (WTD) aims to allow workers to rest and enjoy leisure time.
The Court of Appeal interpreted Article 7 of the WTD to support the appellants' right to take leave during onshore periods.
The court found that the employers' practice does not prevent appellants from taking leave during onshore periods.
The court determined that the employers' practice does not constitute a genuine break.
The court concluded that the employers' practice does not adversely affect the appellants' health or safety.
The court emphasized that the quality of rest periods does not determine WTD compliance.
The case centers on the interpretation of annual leave entitlements under the WTD for offshore workers.
uksc-2016-0052: The UK Supreme Court case involves the enforcement of confiscation orders for drug trafficking.
Confiscation orders are governed by the Drug Trafficking Act 1994 and the Proceeds of Crime Act 2002.
Confiscation orders can include interest on unpaid amounts.
Part payments of confiscation orders are permitted.
The case involved a drug trafficker ordered to pay £5.4 million.
A part payment of £12,000 was made in 2007.
The outstanding amount increased to £8.1 million due to interest.
The court reduced the imprisonment term by 31 days for the part payment and interest.
The Magistrates Court treats confiscation orders as fines for enforcement purposes.
The case clarifies the starting point for calculating imprisonment reductions for part payments.
uksc-2012-0124: The case involves Mohammed Gul Mohammed challenging his conviction under the Terrorism Act 2000.
The defendant was charged with distributing terrorist publications and encouraging terrorism.
The case was heard by the Court of Appeal.
The defendant argued that the term "terrorism" should be read down to exclude armed attacks during armed conflict.
The Crown argued that international treaties should influence the interpretation of the Terrorism Act 2000.
The court found that the absence of an armed conflict exclusion in international treaties does not mean the treaties apply during armed conflict.
The court concluded there is no internationally accepted norm requiring a narrower interpretation of "terrorism."
The court held that the wide definition of terrorism under section 1 of the 2000 Act should not be read down.
The court affirmed the conviction and sentence of Mohammed Gul Mohammed.
The court's decision has significant implications for the prosecution of terrorism-related offences in the UK.
uksc-2009-0127: The case of Logan v Harrower was brought before the UK Supreme Court.
The case involved a challenge to the Scottish Parliament's power to modify a rule of Scots criminal law.
The Scottish Parliament passed legislation increasing sheriffs' summary sentencing powers.
The legislation was challenged on the grounds of modifying the maximum term of imprisonment for a specific offence.
The offence in question was a reserved matter under the Scotland Act 1998.
The Supreme Court held that the Scottish Parliament could not modify a rule of Scots criminal law special to a reserved matter.
The court found the purpose of the legislation did not justify overriding the reserved matter of modifying penal provisions.
The Scotland Act 1998 limits the Scottish Parliament's legislative competence.
The court emphasized that certain matters, including maximum term of imprisonment for specific offences, are reserved to Westminster.
The decision underscores the importance of the reserved matters doctrine in the devolution settlement.
uksc-2013-0266: The UK Supreme Court considered an appeal regarding the English language requirement for non-EU spouses and partners seeking to live in the UK.
The appellants argued that the English language requirement violated their right to private and family life under Article 8 of the ECHR.
The court found the English language requirement to be a legitimate aim for promoting integration into UK society.
The court determined that the requirement was proportionate as it was necessary to achieve its aim and no less intrusive alternatives existed.
The court acknowledged that the requirement could pose a significant obstacle for applicants from countries where English is not widely spoken.
The court suggested that the government should revise guidance to account for cases where learning English or taking the test is impracticable.
The court concluded that the English language requirement was not directly discriminatory based on nationality.
The requirement was deemed a reasonable proxy for ensuring familiarity with English to facilitate community integration.
The court invited submissions from the parties before deciding whether a declaration of incompatibility should be made.
The court held that the English language requirement was a proportionate means of achieving the aim of integration and community contribution.
uksc-2013-0023: The case involves a legal dispute between CMI and LMI against OME and Starlight concerning the application of Article 27 of the Brussels I Regulation.
The dispute centers on whether the English release claims can proceed in light of prior Greek proceedings.
The core issue revolves around the interpretation of what constitutes the "same cause of action" under Article 27.
The appellants argue that the English release claims are the same cause of action as the Greek tort claims.
The appellants base their argument on the belief that the English claims directly challenge the Greek tort claims.
The respondents, represented by Lord Clarke, argue that the English claims and Greek tort claims are fundamentally different.
The respondents contend that the English claims do not seek to enforce the Greek tort claims but rather to declare them as settled or compromised.
Lord Clarke's dissenting opinion references the legal principles established in The Tatry Case and Gubisch v Palumbo.
These cases support the view that actions seeking a declaration of non-liability and enforcement of a claim may be considered the same cause of action if they address the same legal issue.
Lord Clarke argues that the English claims, by asserting that the Greek claims are settled, directly challenge the Greek tort claims and thus cannot be considered the same cause of action.
uksc-2012-0247: The document discusses the legal framework for issuing European arrest warrants in the UK under the Extradition Act 2003.
The cases involve Lithuanian, Latvian, and Russian nationals named Mr. Bucnyss, Mr. Lavrov, and Mr. Sakalis.
The document aims to determine the validity of the European arrest warrants issued in these three cases.
The European arrest warrant for Mr. Bucnyss was found to be valid under the Extradition Act 2003.
The European arrest warrant for Mr. Lavrov was also found to be valid under the Extradition Act 2003.
The European arrest warrant for Mr. Sakalis was determined to be invalid.
The Ministry of Justice and the courts responsible for conviction played a crucial role in ensuring the validity of the warrants.
The invalidity of Mr. Sakalis' warrant was due to the lack of proper judicial authority in its issuance.
The document emphasizes the importance of adhering to the legal framework when issuing European arrest warrants.
Judicial authorities are essential in ensuring the validity of European arrest warrants under the Extradition Act 2003.
uksc-2012-0249: The clinical report discusses legal considerations surrounding the liability of the UK government in military operations.
The report references the judgment of Lord Hope and differing views from Lord Mance.
The Court of Appeal did not address the liability issue in detail.
The trial judge has discretion to determine the UK government's liability.
The policy reasons for excluding liability relate to the special features of war.
The summary argues that the same approach should not apply to peacekeeping operations.
The claimants allege the UK government failed to prevent known risks during military operations.
The summary concludes that such claims should not be excluded as a matter of general policy.
The legal issues include arguments from both sides regarding liability.
The court's decision will influence future cases involving government liability.
uksc-2015-0214: The Supreme Court case A (A Child) (Abduction: Habitual Residence) [2017] UKSC 57 concerns the determination of a child's habitual residence.
The case involves a child, B, who was habitually resident in the United Kingdom before being taken to Pakistan by her mother.
The mother had no legal parental rights in the UK as she was not married to the child's father.
The mother had no parental responsibility order in the UK.
The mother had not made a child arrangements order in the UK.
The mother argued that she had lost her habitual residence in the UK when she moved to Pakistan.
The Supreme Court disagreed with the majority's view that the child's habitual residence in the UK was lost.
Lord Sumption emphasized the factual nature of habitual residence in his judgment.
The judgment highlighted the importance of the child's best interests in determining habitual residence.
The case has significant implications for future international child abduction cases under the Hague Convention.
uksc-2009-0180: The case involves a dispute over the proportionality of a possession order against a demoted tenant.
The case examines the transitional provisions of the Housing and Regeneration Act 2008.
The Supreme Court ruled that the European Convention on Human Rights article 8 could be raised by Mr. Pinnock.
The Supreme Court decided to address the proportionality issue directly rather than remitting the case.
The Council argued that retrospective amendments to the possession order would be against rational legal principles.
Mr. Pinnock did not challenge the Council's proposal on its merits.
Mr. Pinnock claimed the Court could not retrospectively amend Judge Holman's order.
Judge Holman was precluded from making a possession order effective more than six weeks after 22 December 2008.
The Supreme Court set aside the possession order made by Judge Holman.
The Supreme Court substituted a new possession order to take effect on 10 March 2011.
uksc-2010-0106: The case of A v Secretary of State for the Home Department [2011] UKSC 60 involves closed material procedures in employment tribunals.
The case examines the compatibility of closed material procedures with Article 6 of the ECHR.
The Court of Appeal ruled that closed material procedures do not inherently violate Article 6 of the ECHR.
Lord Dyson agreed with the Court of Appeal's decision but emphasized the need for sufficient information for a fair trial.
Special advocates are appointed to represent the state's interests in cases involving sensitive information.
The case explores the balance between national security and the right to a fair trial.
The European Court of Human Rights (ECtHR) has interpreted the balance between national security and fair trial rights.
The summary distinguishes between Article 6 and Article 8 cases in the ECHR.
The ECtHR has held that Article 6 does not apply in the same way to cases involving Article 8 rights.
The case of A v Secretary of State for the Home Department has implications for future legal cases.
uksc-2012-0143: The appellant was extradited from the USA to the UK for criminal offences.
The appellant was subsequently extradited back to the USA for contempt of court.
The appellant argued that the UK courts could not handle his contempt due to the specialty provisions of the Extradition Act 2003.
The Crown Court ruled that the appellant's contempt was criminal, not civil.
The Court of Appeal dismissed the appeal.
The Court of Appeal held that a contempt of court is not a crime itself.
The court determined that section 151A of the Extradition Act 2003 does not prevent the UK courts from dealing with contempt.
The court also found that article 18 of the UK-US Extradition Treaty 2003 does not bar the UK courts from addressing contempt.
The court emphasized that civil contempt is not limited to civil courts.
The ruling ensures a clear distinction between civil and criminal contempt in the legal system.
uksc-2009-0022: The case involves the appellants Lumba and Mighty challenging their detention under the Immigration Act 1971.
The appellants argue that the Secretary of State failed to conduct required reviews of their detention's justification.
The Secretary of State claims the detention is lawful despite the alleged failure to conduct reviews.
The appellants reference the case of R (Walker) v Secretary of State for Justice.
The House of Lords in R (Walker) v Secretary of State for Justice held that failure to conduct reviews did not render detention unlawful.
The respondent argues that R (Walker) is not directly applicable due to differences in statutory requirements.
The Court of Appeal's decision in Roberts v Chief Constable of the Cheshire Constabulary is considered.
The Court of Appeal held that failure to conduct a review within a specified time did not render detention unlawful.
The majority of the court in Lumba found the Secretary of State liable for false imprisonment.
The liability was due to the failure to comply with the review policy for the appellants awaiting deportation.
uksc-2013-0161: The case involves Ms Mirga and Mr Samin seeking income support and housing assistance under UK law.
The eligibility of Ms Mirga for income support is contested based on her status as a worker under EU regulations.
Ms Mirga has not completed 12 months of work in the UK.
The 2004 Directive limits the right of residence to workers, self-employed, students, or self-sufficient persons.
The 2003 Accession Treaty aims to prevent EU nationals from becoming an unreasonable burden on the host state's social assistance system.
Mr Samin's eligibility for housing assistance is contested based on his status as a self-sufficient person.
Mr Samin is unable to work due to permanent incapacity.
The CJEU clarified that the right to reside in an EU member state is not absolute.
The CJEU held that the UK's interpretation of the EU regulations was correct.
The case revolves around the interpretation of TFEU articles 21 and 24 in relation to EU nationals' rights in the UK.
uksc-2013-0057: The case involved a dispute between a claimant and an insurer over mesothelioma liability.
The claimant was exposed to asbestos at work and developed mesothelioma.
The claimant sought compensation from the insurer under a policy covering personal injury caused by negligence.
The insurer denied liability, arguing the policy did not cover mesothelioma.
The Court of Appeal ruled in favor of the insurer.
The Supreme Court upheld the Court of Appeal's decision.
The Supreme Court ruled the insurer was not liable for the claimant's mesothelioma.
The policy only covered personal injury caused by the insured's negligence.
The court found the claimant's mesothelioma was not caused by the insured's negligence.
The decision highlights the importance of reviewing insurance policy wording.
uksc-2014-0087: Mr. Khans was employed by the respondent to attend to customers and respond to their inquiries.
Mr. Khans engaged in inappropriate behavior towards Mr. Smith.
Mr. Khans answered Mr. Smith's request in a foul-mouthed manner.
Mr. Khans ordered Mr. Smith to leave.
Mr. Khans followed Mr. Smith onto the forecourt.
The claimant argued that the respondent should be held vicariously liable for Mr. Khans' actions.
The legal principle of vicarious liability holds employers responsible for the actions of their employees within the scope of employment.
The court applied the 'close connection' test to determine vicarious liability.
The court found a close connection between Mr. Khans' employment and his wrongful conduct.
The court concluded that the respondent was vicariously liable for Mr. Khans' wrongful conduct towards Mr. Smith.
uksc-2012-0025: The case involves the Law Reform (Miscellaneous Provisions) (Scotland) Act 1995, specifically section 10(1).
The Act simplifies the tripartite test from Caparo Industries plc v Dickman.
The Act removes the need to prove a special relationship between parties.
The Act focuses on foreseeability of harm and reliance on misrepresentation.
The claimant, Cramaso, was created by Mr. Erskine for a lease agreement.
The claim was based on a negligent misrepresentation by an agent of the trustees.
The Lord Ordinary initially concluded no duty of care existed between the trustees and Cramaso.
The court challenged the Lord Ordinary's decision regarding the timing of the misrepresentation.
The court found the trustees breached their duty by making a negligent misrepresentation.
The court applied the principle from Esso v. Central Wales Agricultural Executive Ltd.
uksc-2014-0094: The Complaints Commissioner investigated a complaint made by Mrs. R against a general practitioner (GP).
The Commissioner found that the GP had failed to provide necessary care and treatment.
The Commissioner recommended that the GP should be held accountable for maladministration.
The Commissioner also recommended that Mrs. R should be compensated for the harm she suffered.
The court ruled that the Commissioner did not have the power to recommend monetary redress.
The court found that the Commissioner's recommendations were not legally binding on the GP.
The Commissioner's recommendations were considered as rebuttable evidence of the facts.
The GP was entitled to dispute the Commissioner's recommendations in court.
The court held that the Commissioner had no authority to recommend compensation for Mrs. R.
The court determined that the Commissioner's recommendations could be challenged in legal proceedings.
uksc-2012-0181: The UK Supreme Court case involves a child named AA who was adopted by her brother's wife.
The court examined the legal framework and international obligations related to children's rights and family definitions.
The court ruled that the legal definition of adoption does not include other forms of de facto adoption.
The court determined there is no clear international consensus on the issue of de facto adoption.
The court agreed with the Secretary of State for Home Department that domestic adoption rules do not exhaust international obligations.
The court acknowledged the importance of the best interests principle in international law.
The court concluded that the best interests principle does not create a specific obligation of customary international law for de facto adopted children.
The court stated that adoption rules should not discriminate against de facto adopted children.
The court recognized the need for clear definitions to establish boundaries in adoption laws.
The court emphasized the importance of aligning adoption rules with the Secretary of State's actual practices and international obligations.
uksc-2012-0162: The case involves the interpretation of "earnings" under Section 2 of the Social Contributions Act 1992.
The dispute centered on whether a transfer of assets to a trust constituted earnings for NICs purposes.
The transfer was made by a company, FML, for the benefit of its director, Mr. McHugh.
The court ruled that the transfer of assets to a trust was not considered an earning for NICs.
The court emphasized that the focus should be on what the earner received, not just what was paid.
Mr. McHugh transferred his entitlement to a pension fund to a trust.
The court found that the transfer did not give Mr. McHugh an immediate right to receive cash or assets.
The court highlighted the contingent nature of Mr. McHugh's future benefits from the trust.
The court disagreed with HMRC's approach of treating the transfer as a payment of earnings.
The court concluded that "earnings" in the 1992 Act refers to remuneration derived from employment.
uksc-2009-0152: The case concerns the interpretation of Article 3(1) of the Product Liability Directive.
The claimant argued that APMSD, a wholly owned subsidiary of APSA, should be substituted for APSA in the proceedings.
The claimant contended that the transfer of the product to APMSD should be considered as putting the product into circulation by APSA.
The European Court of Justice rejected the claimant's argument regarding substitution.
The ECJ emphasized that the domestic court must assess whether APSA controlled APMSD and determined when the product was put into circulation.
The ECJ held that APMSD was integrated into the manufacturing process and tightly controlled by APSA.
The ECJ concluded that the supplier's status as a wholly owned subsidiary does not automatically allow for substitution.
The ECJ noted that the claimant's argument assumed automatic substitution based on subsidiary status.
The ECJ stated that the domestic court must evaluate the circumstances of control and product circulation.
The ECJ held that APMSD could not be substituted for APSA in the proceedings.
uksc-2012-0179: The UK was required to comply with the Air Quality Directive (Directive 2008/50/EC) to protect human health and the environment from air pollution.
The UK submitted air quality plans for Greater London and non-compliant zones.
The European Commission objected to 12 of the 24 applications for time extensions by the UK.
The UK failed to request time extensions for 17 zones where nitrogen dioxide (NO2) limits were exceeded.
The ClientEarth environmental group argued that the UK was in breach of the Air Quality Directive.
The UK government claimed practical difficulties and expenses made compliance by the deadline unrealistic.
The UK Supreme Court upheld the High Court's decision that the UK was in breach of the Air Quality Directive.
The Supreme Court found the UK government had not adequately demonstrated the justification for non-compliance.
The Court noted the UK government failed to show it had taken all reasonable steps to comply with the directive.
The UK government was required to take immediate action to comply with the Air Quality Directive.
uksc-2017-0096: Mr Holden was insured by UKI under a Motor Insurance Policy.
The policy covers liability for damage to property caused by accidents involving the insured vehicle.
A fire occurred during the repair of Mr Holden's car at R & P S Ltd.
The fire caused damage to property.
UKI denied coverage for the damage caused by the fire.
Mr Holden appealed the High Court's decision.
The appeal involved the interpretation of the Road Traffic Act 1988.
The appeal also involved the interpretation of the Motor Insurance Directive 2009/103/EC.
The UK Supreme Court upheld the interpretation of the RTA and the Motor Insurance Directive by the Court of Appeal.
The Supreme Court ruled that the insurance policy must cover accidents caused by or arising out of the use of a vehicle on a public place.
uksc-2018-0132: Mr. Watkins filed a professional negligence claim against the appellant.
The appellant sent a letter on 18 February 2003, which was deemed negligent.

The judge found that Mr. Watkins' claim had no value because the damages he received were more than the 9,478 he had already been paid.
The appellant argued the court should consider all evidence available at the time of the trial.
The respondent argued the court should assess the prospects of success as at the time the claim was lost.
The court held that the evidence of Mr. Tennant was not relevant to the professional negligence proceedings.
The court emphasized that the Scheme was designed to provide an efficient and economic system for dealing with claims.
uksc-2018-0131: The patent in question relates to a method for creating transgenic mice that produce hybrid antibodies with human variable regions and mouse constant regions.
The patent includes a claim for modifying the immunoglobulin heavy chain locus in mouse embryonic stem cells.
The patent claim involves replacing murine V, D, and J gene segments with human counterparts.
The patent also includes a claim for replacing murine V and J gene segments with human V and J gene segments.
The Court of Appeal ruled that the claim was not limited to a single product but included mice with varying amounts of human and murine gene segments replaced.
The Court of Appeal found that the claim extended to a mouse with the entire murine variable gene locus replaced by the entire human variable gene locus.
The legal question concerns whether a product patent that enables some, but not all, products within the claim scope passes the sufficiency test.
The majority of the Court of Appeal held that the patent failed to enable the skilled person to make all products within the claim scope.
The Supreme Court majority found that the patent failed to enable the making of a mouse with a significant amount of human variable region incorporation.
The Supreme Court majority argued that the claims should enable a substantial range of human variable region incorporation in mice.
uksc-2020-0042: The Supreme Court upheld the designation of the North West Rural Development Programme (NWRDP) as an Annex I National Rural Development Programme (ANPS).
The Friends of the Earth (FoE) challenged the designation, arguing it did not consider environmental impacts of non-CO2 emissions.
The Secretary of State focused on CO2 emissions in the decision-making process.

The decision was made in the context of the government's development of its Aviation Strategy.
The designation of the ANPS was the first stage in a process for the NWR Scheme to proceed.
The Secretary of State had powers at the DCO stage to address non-CO2 emissions.
uksc-2011-0089: Mr. Griffiths sought tax planning advice in January 2003.

uksc-2011-0011: The UK Supreme Court reviewed appeals regarding the refugee status of three individuals: RT, SM, and AM.
The central issue in each case was whether the individuals could demonstrate loyalty to the Zimbabwean regime.

The court dismissed the appeal in SM's case and remitted it to the Tribunal for further consideration.
The court dismissed the appeal in AM's case and remitted it to the Tribunal for further consideration.
The court allowed the appeal in KM's case, stating that the case was very strong.

The court allowed the appeal of KM.
The court remitted the cases of RT, SM, and AM to the Tribunal for further consideration.
uksc-2011-0244: The case of Hoffmann La Roche dealt with the legal principles surrounding the requirement of a cross undertaking in damages.
The Crown is not subject to the same constraints as private litigants in cases involving cross undertakings.
The House of Lords held that the Crown should not be inhibited from enforcing the law by the fear of public funds being exposed to compensation claims.
The court distinguished between private litigation and law enforcement action in the Hoffmann La Roche case.

The court in Director General of Fair Trading v Tobyward Ltd required a cross undertaking to protect the proprietary interests of a charity.

uksc-2014-0159: The Hastings Council closed a section of the Hastings Pier to the public due to safety concerns.

uksc-2016-0080: A book titled *Le Grand Secret* was published by the doctor of deceased President Mitterand.

Mr Shankland was a disgruntled colleague of Mr Mohamud.
Mr Shankland had been dismissed by WM Morrison Supermarkets plc.
Mr Shankland accessed the supermarket's computer system.
Mr Shankland posted a list of employees' personal data online.
Mr Mohamud was attacked by a customer who was upset by the posted information.
The court ruled that WM Morrison Supermarkets plc was not vicariously liable for Mr Shankland's actions.
The court found that Mr Shankland's actions were not carried out in the course of his employment.
The court emphasized that employers have a duty to protect employees and customers from harm.
The court noted that this duty does not extend to actions taken by dismissed employees outside of their employment.
uksc-2014-0023: The appellant appealed against the Secretary of State's approval of the 2012/13 revenue budget.
The appellant claimed the decision was unlawful under section 149 of the Equality Act 2010.

The Court of Appeal considered the issue of costs due to the appellant's success on statutory duty issues.
The Court of Appeal concluded the appeal had no practical value and was destined to fail.
uksc-2010-0244: The UK Supreme Court ruled that the general rule of costs does not apply when a local authority makes unfounded allegations against an intervening party.
The court allowed the appeal and restored Judge Dowses's original order.
The court concluded that it is just to not award costs against a party, including a local authority, in the absence of reprehensible behavior or an unreasonable stance.
The court distinguished between the question of awarding costs against a public authority and the question of public funding for litigants.
The Funding Code prepared by the Legal Services Commission provides for public funding in proceedings under the Children Act 1989.
Public funding under the Funding Code is not available to interveners in care proceedings.
The court emphasized the importance of considering the specific circumstances of each case when determining costs.
The court highlighted the potential financial burden on local authorities and the limited funds available to them.
The court noted that the general practice of not awarding costs aligns with the ends of justice.
The ruling has implications for how costs are awarded in care proceedings involving unfounded allegations by local authorities.
uksc-2017-0106: The case concerns the application of the 1951 Refugee Convention to the Sovereign Base Areas (SBAs) of Cyprus.
The SBAs are British territories located on the island of Cyprus.
The Republic of Cyprus (RoC) is a separate state from the SBAs.
The UK has provided support to refugees in the SBAs through a Memorandum of Understanding (MoU) with the RoC.
The court found that the Refugee Convention applies to the SBAs.
The UK has an obligation to resettle refugees in the UK under the Refugee Convention.
The 2003 MoU between the UK and the RoC is a valid basis for fulfilling the UK's obligations under the Convention.
The MoU provides for the support of refugees in the SBAs.
The MoU does not require the UK to resettle refugees in the UK.
The MoU is an international agreement that does not provide rights enforceable in domestic law.
uksc-2019-0028: The case involves Ali Shafi Ali, who was convicted under the Torture Act 2000 for his role in the torture of detainees in Northern Ireland.
The case raises the question of whether Ali Shafi Ali was acting in an official capacity under the United Nations Convention Against Torture (UNCAT).
The court considered a broader definition of "acting in an official capacity" that includes any person acting under the color of law of a State.
The court referenced the case of Zardad v Powers, where a de facto public official was considered to be acting in an official capacity under UNCAT.
The court emphasized that the definition of official capacity should reflect the actual control and authority exercised by the entity.
The court found that the Alien Tort Statute (ATS) and UNCAT can be applied to cases of torture by non-state actors.
The court supported the prosecution's argument that the ATS and UNCAT do not require the involvement of a state official for a torture act to be considered official.
The court noted that the scope of UNCAT is limited to torture that occurs in the context of governmental authority.
The court distinguished between governmental functions and purely military activity, noting that insurrectional forces may still exercise sufficient governmental authority.
The court concluded that the appellant was not acting in an official capacity, as the insurgents were not in de facto control of the area.
uksc-2010-0236: The case involves a dispute over the interpretation of the Competition Act 1998.
The Competition Appeal Tribunal (CAT) is the UK's specialist tribunal for competition law cases.
The Competition Act 1998 implements EU competition rules into UK law.
The Act prohibits anti-competitive agreements under Section 1.
The Act prohibits abuse of a dominant position under Section 2.
The Act prohibits mergers that may significantly impede effective competition under Section 3.
The Act allows for the imposition of penalties on parties that infringe its provisions.
The claimant, BCL, is seeking damages under Section 47A of the Competition Act 1998.
The OFT found that the Competition Act 1998 was unclear and breached the principle of legal certainty.
The CAT dismissed BCL's appeal, ruling that the principle of legal certainty does not require setting aside a civil defence due to a State's failure to provide legal certainty.
uksc-2018-0225: The Upper Tribunal and the Court of Appeal agreed that ATM sites are capable of being separate hereditaments for rating purposes.
A specific moveable ATM at Tescos Nottingham store was excluded from being separately rateable.
The retailers argued that ATM sites are integral to the overall business of the store and should not be separately rateable.
The Court of Appeal found that ATM sites are distinct from the rest of the store as they are designed or adapted for ATMs.
The Court of Appeal determined that ATM sites are not rival occupations.
The retailers retain control over the store, which does not interfere with the bank's occupation of the ATM sites.
The Court of Appeal allowed the retailers' appeals in respect of external ATMs.
The Valuation Officers' appeal in respect of internal ATM sites was dismissed.
The retailers were found to have sufficient control over ATM sites to be regarded as in rateable occupation.
The Court of Appeal concluded that ATM sites should be considered part of the retailers' rateable occupation.
uksc-2017-0214: The UK Supreme Court's judgment in Abbott Respiratory LLC/Dosage regime (G 0002/08) addresses the patentability of dosage regimes under the EPC.
The case is significant for the pharmaceutical industry due to the complexity and cost of developing new dosage regimes.
The EPC requires inventions to be new and involve an inventive step for patentability.
Inventiveness involves comparing the claimed invention to the state of the art and assessing obviousness to a skilled person.
The skilled person's knowledge, skills, and expectations are crucial in determining the obviousness of an invention.
The judgment emphasizes that a novel dosage regime for a known medication can be patentable if it meets the requirements of novelty and non-obviousness.
A new technical effect is a key factor in assessing the inventiveness of a dosage regime.
The decision clarifies the legal framework for assessing the patentability of dosage regimes under the EPC.
The judgment highlights the importance of inventiveness and non-obviousness in pharmaceutical patents.
The case has significant implications for patent law, particularly in the pharmaceutical industry.
uksc-2012-0007: The fingerprinting device used was not approved by the relevant authorities.
The appellants argued that the fingerprints should not be admissible in court.

The Court of Appeal found the fingerprints to be admissible.

uksc-2012-0250: The case involved a non-British citizen granted indefinite leave to remain in the UK since 2007.

The court emphasized that section 5(2) of the Immigration Act 1971 was not intended to provide automatic revival of leave to remain.
The Secretary of State retains discretion to reassess an individual's status after revocation of a deportation order.
The court reviewed the legislative history of the 1971 Act to understand the intent behind revocation provisions.
The court applied the literal, golden, and mischief rules of statutory interpretation.

The decision balanced the revocation of a deportation order against the individual's Convention rights.
The case provides a detailed analysis of the legal framework surrounding deportation and leave to remain.
uksc-2016-0210: The pension scheme's rules included the phrase "replacement or replaced or re based."
The phrase was interpreted to allow the trustees to choose an alternative index to the RPI.
The Retail Prices Index (RPI) was the original measure for indexation of benefits.
The Court of Appeal ruled that an alternative index could be used if it was suitable.
The use of an alternative index was subject to not prejudicing the CIR's approval.
The draftsman of the scheme did not use the word "alternative" in the definition.
The defendant, Barnardos, appealed the decision, arguing for a stricter interpretation.
The Court of Appeal dismissed the appeal, supporting the interpretation allowing an alternative index.
The court emphasized the importance of textual analysis in interpreting pension scheme rules.
The scheme's rules were related to an Appendix containing the CIR's limits on pension payments.
uksc-2017-0083: The Facilities Grant was given to the Regency Villas timeshare owners in 1981.
The grant provided free access to recreational facilities within a leisure complex in the Park.
The recreational facilities included a golf course, tennis courts, and swimming pool.
The dispute arose over the use of a new indoor swimming pool constructed after the grant.
The Court of Appeal ruled that the grant did not include the new indoor swimming pool.
The Court of Appeal distinguished between outdoor and indoor facilities in its ruling.
The judge disagreed with the Court of Appeal's interpretation of the grant.
The judge argued that the grant should allow access to the new indoor swimming pool.
The judge interpreted the grant as a simple easement allowing recreational facility access.
The judge believed the grant did not restrict dominant owners from making improvements to the leisure complex.
uksc-2015-0255: The case involves a legal challenge to a proposal for a residence test for civil legal aid in England and Wales.
The proposal was part of the Legal Aid, Sentencing and Punishment of Offenders Act 2012 (LASPO).
The Public Law Project contested the proposal, claiming it was unlawful.
The Public Law Project argued the proposal was ultra vires.
The Public Law Project also claimed the proposal was discriminatory.
The Supreme Court upheld the Divisional Court's decision to nullify the draft order.
The Supreme Court found the draft order was ultra vires.
The Supreme Court did not consider the discrimination argument.
The parties did not present the discrimination argument to the Court.
The purpose of Part 1 of LASPO was to direct civil legal aid based on specific criteria.
uksc-2014-0079: The UK Supreme Court is examining the impact of the benefit cap on women who are victims of domestic violence.
The benefit cap limits the total amount of benefits a household can receive.
The government aims to incentivize work and create a fairer system between working and non-working households.
The court will assess whether the differential treatment under the benefit cap is justified.
The government's margin of appreciation is considered in balancing the public interest.
The case raises questions about the fairness and effectiveness of the benefit cap.
The government's obligations towards lone parents and their children are under scrutiny.
The influence of international law, particularly the UNCRC, on domestic policy is a key issue.
The Court of Appeal found the Secretary of State did not prioritize the best interests of the child in implementing the benefit cap.
Lord Carnwath argues that the best interests of the child should be the primary consideration in determining the proportionality of the benefit cap.
uksc-2009-0129: The appellant was convicted of drug offenses based on the testimony of Mr. Stronach.
The defense counsel cross-examined Mr. Stronach, highlighting inconsistencies in his story.
The defense counsel argued that the appellant had been seen in the vicinity of his house on the day of the alleged sale.
The defense counsel pointed out that the appellant had been seen driving a Peugeot near his house shortly before the arrest.
The defense counsel also noted that the appellant had been seen driving the same car to a police station in Aberdeen to obtain a driving license.
The jury was instructed to consider the credibility of Mr. Stronach's testimony.
The jury was told to be selective in their approach to the evidence presented.
The jury ultimately found the appellant guilty of the drug offenses.
The appellant argued that the Crown failed to disclose outstanding charges against Mr. Stronach.
The appeal court found that the failure to disclose these charges did not result in an unfair trial or miscarriage of justice.
uksc-2014-0110: The Littlewoods Group permanently ceased its trade.
The case involves whether post-cessation VAT repayments (VRP2) should be subject to corporation tax.
The group transferred rights to VAT repayments for no consideration.
The court ruled that transferring VAT repayment rights for no consideration does not trigger a charge to corporation tax under section 103.
The transfer of the trade of SDG to RGL was not for value.
The transfer of RGL's trade back to SDG was also not for value.
Section 106(1) is not applicable to the transactions in question.
There was no evidence of intra-group transfers involving transfers for value.
Section 106(2) is not applicable to the transactions in question.
The court dismissed the appeal, finding no tax should be charged on the transferors.
uksc-2016-0082: The case involves Mrs. Robinson and a police officer.
The case concerns legal principles of duty of care and negligence.
The case references Hill v Chief Constabulary of the West Midlands [1989].
The case references Brooks v Chief Constable of West Yorkshire Police [2004].
The case references Smith v Littlewoods Organisation Ltd [1987].
The court found that the police officer owed no duty of care to Mrs. Robinson.
The police officer's decision to arrest the suspect directly caused Mrs. Robinson's physical harm.
The court agreed with the trial judge's finding of negligence.
The court emphasized that appellate courts should not second-guess trial judges' decisions.
The case was remitted to the court of trial for the assessment of damages.
uksc-2018-0030: The Attorney General for Northern Ireland applied to the Supreme Court to refer a devolution issue to the court.
The application is based on the argument that Universal Credit provisions breach articles 8, 12, and 14 of the ECHR.
The application also claims the provisions breach article 1 of the first protocol to the ECHR.
The Attorney General argues the provisions are invalid under section 24 of the Northern Ireland Act 1998.
The Department for Communities is involved in preparing postcodes lists necessary for Universal Credit implementation.
The Supreme Court refused to accept the Attorney General's application to refer the issue to the court.
The court determined that preparing postcode lists is not sufficient to constitute a devolution issue.
The Attorney General's case is based on the incompatibility of Universal Credit with the ECHR.
The court noted that the preparation of postcode lists is not the primary issue in the Attorney General's case.
The Attorney General may apply to intervene in an appeal on the compatibility of Universal Credit with the ECHR.
uksc-2017-0006: The case involves the interpretation of section 92(1)(b) of the UK Trade Marks Act 1994.
The appellants argue that the mental element for criminal liability under the 1994 Act was more stringent than in the 1938 Act.
The appellants claim the 1994 Act did not intend to change the mental element from the 1938 Act.
The appellants argue that the current interpretation could result in criminal liability for the sale of grey market goods.
The court disagrees with the appellants' interpretation of the mental element in the 1994 Act.
The court finds that the 1994 Act did not intend to change the effect of the more stringent mental element from the 1938 Act.
The court rejects the argument that grey market goods could lead to criminal liability under the current interpretation.
The court emphasizes that both grey market goods and counterfeit goods infringe on the rights of the trade mark proprietor.
The court notes that the 1994 Act regulates the use or disposal of goods, not the deprivation of property.
The court concludes that the Act balances the rights of the trade mark proprietor and the seller of goods.
uksc-2019-0001: The UK Supreme Court allowed the appeal regarding the listing of garden and park structures.
The court stated that the enforcement appeal must be remitted to the Secretary of State for redetermination.
The court noted a lack of clarity in the criteria for determining if free-standing items qualify for listing protection.
The judgment discussed the extended definition of a listed building.
The court focused on the treatment of garden objects or structures as buildings.
The judgment addressed the criteria for determining if garden objects qualify as listed buildings in their own right.
The court emphasized the importance of legal challenges to the listing process.
The court highlighted the presumption that the accused may raise any relevant defense.
The judgment discussed the limited protection available for gardens and parks.
The court mentioned the Skerritts test, which considers size, permanence, and degree of physical attachment.
uksc-2013-0158: The Olympic Pension Scheme sought to open secondary insolvency proceedings against Olympic Pension Scheme Ltd in the UK.
Olympic Pension Scheme Ltd has its centre of main interests (COMI) in Greece.
The Chancellor initially found that Olympic Pension Scheme Ltd had an establishment in the UK.
The UK establishment was defined as a place of operations with non-transitory economic activity involving human resources and goods.
The company had three remaining employees in the UK at the time.
The Supreme Court ruled that Olympic Pension Scheme Ltd did not have an establishment in the UK.
Activities at the UK office included handling lease liabilities, Companies Act filings, and legal/accountancy advice.
The court determined that these activities were transitory and not economic in nature.
The company was in liquidation in Luxembourg at the time of the proceedings.
The court emphasized that an establishment must involve economic activities exercised on the market with the debtor's assets and human agents.
uksc-2014-0231: The clinical report discusses the legal framework for policing parades in Northern Ireland.
The report examines the application of the Public Processions Act 1998 in the context of unnotified parades.
The document addresses the European Convention on Human Rights (ECHR) in relation to parade policing.
The Supreme Court reaffirmed the importance of the 1998 Act in preserving the notification requirement.
The Court held that the police's response to parades was based on the need to prevent violence and disorder.
The 1998 Act has not been undermined by the police's actions.
The police do not have the power to ban parades but have legal authority to stop them.
The document clarifies misconceptions held by the police regarding their powers to stop parades.
The 1998 Act is essential for the successful implementation of the Parades Commission.
The police must consider the possibility of violence and disorder when responding to parades.
